Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Description:\nThree-pair cyclic entanglement router in the telecom C-band via abstracted Kerr parity checks\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optical network that \u201crotates\u201d three Bell-pair links in a cycle among three sender\u2013receiver pairs, without any active feed-forward.  Concretely, three independent telecom-band Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083 respectively emit modes (A\u2081,B\u2081), (A\u2082,B\u2082), (A\u2083,B\u2083).  The B-modes {B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083} enter a single multiport interferometer (at the \u201crouter\u201d node) together with six ancilla vacuum modes.  Four of the ancilla photons plus number-resolving detectors implement pairwise parity projections (abstracting a cross-Kerr nonlinearity), and the remaining two ancillas complete the routing unitary.  Conditioned on a unique six-click pattern across the ancilla detectors, the network heralds the transformation:\n\n    A\u2081 \u2194 B\u2081    becomes    A\u2081 \u2194 C\u2082  \n    A\u2082 \u2194 B\u2082    becomes    A\u2082 \u2194 C\u2083  \n    A\u2083 \u2194 B\u2083    becomes    A\u2083 \u2194 C\u2081  \n\nwhere {C\u2081,C\u2082,C\u2083} are the three output ports of the router.  In other words, the original Bell links are cyclically permuted (1\u21922\u21923\u21921).  This is the simplest \u201ck-cycle\u201d entanglement-routing primitive for k=3, generalizing the two-pair butterfly/swap router to three pairs.  Physically one could implement the parity steps by cross-Kerr resonators in the telecom band; here we encode them abstractly as ancilla-photon parity projections.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes (A\u2081,B\u2081)  \n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes (A\u2082,B\u2082)  \n   \u2022 S\u2083 \u2192 modes (A\u2083,B\u2083)  \n\u2013 Router node:  \n   \u2022 Inputs B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 plus ancilla vacua in modes {4,5,6,7,8,9}  \n   \u2022 Fixed linear-optics network mixing these nine modes  \n   \u2022 Ancilla detectors on modes 4\u20139  \n\u2013 Outputs:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 A\u2081\u2019s partner C\u2082  \n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 A\u2082\u2019s partner C\u2083  \n   \u2022 Mode 2 \u2192 A\u2083\u2019s partner C\u2081  \n\u2013 Target quantum on output modes [0,1,2,3,4,5] (ordering [A\u2081,C\u2082, A\u2082,C\u2083, A\u2083,C\u2081]) is the product of three Bell correlations:\n    [\u2018000000\u2019, \u2018001001\u2019, \u2018010010\u2019, \u2018011011\u2019, \u2018100100\u2019, \u2018101101\u2019, \u2018110110\u2019, \u2018111111\u2019]\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Three-pair cyclic entanglement router (teleC-cycle3)',\n  'foldername':            'teleCycle3',\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'edges_tried':           40,\n  'ftol':                  1e-06,\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'samples':               20,\n  'num_anc':               6,\n  'anc_detectors':         [4,5,6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':   [],  # no direct links among A_i\u2192C_j\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':             False,\n  'target_quantum':        ['000000','001001','010010','011011','100100','101101','110110','111111'],\n  'thresholds':            [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to k-cycle routers for arbitrary k by adding k Bell sources and 2k ancillas  \n\u2013 Chain multiple cycle modules to weave complex network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark trade-offs between abstract Kerr strength (parity-projection fidelity) and pure linear-optics success probability  \n\nThis cyclic router is a new class of photonic telecom-band network primitive\u2014fully abstracted for Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics+ancilla framework and ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation."
}

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. This module is then used to purify a Bell link shared between Alice\u2013Bob and Bob\u2013Charlie, yielding a higher-fidelity Alice\u2013Charlie Bell pair conditioned on a successful parity outcome.\n\n  B) A three-node repeater link that chains two parity-check modules (as in A) with entanglement swapping, implementing a nested purification+swapping protocol entirely in telecom band. Physically the local operations at the repeater nodes would exploit Kerr nonlinearity, but Pytheus just sees two sequential parity projections and a final Bell-swap measurement.\n\n  C) A measurement-based CZ gate between two remote telecom-band qubits using a small entanglement-resource and a single cross-Kerr-enabled parity check. Abstractly this is a teleportation of a CZ gate: Bob performs a joint parity check on one qubit from each resource pair, projecting onto an even/odd subspace and thereby enacting a non-local CZ between Alice and Charlie.\n\nStep 2: Novelty check and Pytheus obstacles:\n\n  A) Novel because past experiments cover only plain entanglement swapping and gates, not purification. Pytheus can implement ancilla\u2010assisted projective measurements and two probabilistic pair sources, so no obstacle.\n\n  B) Builds on A but more complex; likely too heavy for a first Pytheus run and mixes two modules\u2014still feasible but less focused.\n\n  C) A teleportation\u2010gate primitive is original but resembles heralded CNOT/Toffoli gates already explored. Also demands accurate single-click sign shift which Pytheus may struggle to optimize without state generation.\n\nStep 3: Choose A as most promising: it\u2019s a single network primitive, directly leverages parity measurement from Kerr, clearly generalizes to multi\u2010link repeaters and purification chains, and fits Pytheus\u2019s toolkit (probabilistic pair sources + ancilla detectors + post-selection).\n\nStep 4: \u201cThis idea is novel because no previous Pytheus target implements a heralded parity measurement for entanglement purification between two Bell links in the telecom band. It extends swapping protocols into purification territory.\u201d\n\nStep 5: \u201cThis idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only requires two probabilistic photon-pair sources, a small ancilla\u2010assisted linear-optical network for parity projection, and post-selected two-click events\u2014exactly the primitives Pytheus can optimize. It avoids dynamic feedback control, hyper-entanglement, or explicit Kerr modeling, while still abstractly encoding the cross-Kerr parity check as a two-mode projector.\u201d\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded entanglement purification via cross-Kerr parity check in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to purify two noisy Bell links\u2014one between Alice & Bob, and one between Bob & Charlie\u2014by performing at Bob a nondestructive even-parity projection on his two qubits. Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. To be novel, you must go beyond a single parity projection\u2014e.g. embed this in a genuinely new network architecture, introduce coherent superpositions of purification orders, indefinite causal-order purification, or integrate it with another fundamentally new operation rather than just repackaging the textbook gate.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes [B\u2032,C]\n\u2013 Linear-optics network at Bob mixing modes B, B\u2032, plus two ancilla inputs\n\u2013 Detectors:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output (A)\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output (C)\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 parity-check ancilla detectors\n   \u2022 Modes 4,5 \u2192 swap-Bell-measurement ancilla detectors\n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source from Alice to Charlie\n\u2013 num_anc: 4 (ancilla detectors 2,3 for parity + 4,5 for Bell swap)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]\n\u2013 target_quantum on modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom repeater module: merged purification+swapping',\n  'foldername':  'telePurSwap',\n  'bulk_thr':     0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol':         1e-06,\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'num_anc':      4,\n  'num_pre':      1,\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':    False,\n  'samples':      10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'thresholds':   [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple modules to form nested repeater links  \n\u2013 Swap\u2010purify in different orders or multiplex them  \n\u2013 Benchmark optimal C-band Kerr cross-phase strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs\n\nThis network primitive opens a new class of repeater designs\u2014fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying physical Kerr-resonator implementation in the telecom band.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your module is too close to the previously suggested \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater\u201d from the ensemble. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # forbid unwanted cross-links\n  'target_quantum': ['1'],           # herald one photon at output when all clicks succeed\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'edges_tried':  30,\n  'samples':      10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to (k,n) threshold schemes by adding more Bell-pair channels and an n-qubit parity check  \n\u2013 Vary the underlying cross-Kerr strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs  \n\u2013 Switch teleportation order or distribute shares across frequency/time bins  \n\nThis is the first demonstration of a multipartite quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom band, leveraging an abstract Kerr-enabled joint measurement, and opens the door to threshold protocols and networked quantum cryptography.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Secret-sharing by sequential teleportation and parity checks is already well-known (HBB99 and subsequent photonic implementations). Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. The control qubit is in mode 0; the two target qubits to be conditionally swapped are in modes 1 and 2. Physically one would exploit a Kerr nonlinear microresonator to implement the required cross-phase shifts, but here we abstract that nonlinearity into two ancilla-assisted parity measurements implemented by a fixed linear-optics network and four ancilla photons. Conditioned on a unique four-click event in the ancilla detectors, the optical circuit enacts:\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2081, t\u2082\u27e9   if c=0\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2082, t\u2081\u27e9   if c=1\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at sources:\n    \u2022 mode 0 (control)  \n    \u2022 mode 1 (target 1)  \n    \u2022 mode 2 (target 2)  \n\u2013 Ancilla vacuum inputs at modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixing modes 0\u20136 (to be optimized by Pytheus).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 Output modes 0,1\u2032,2\u2032 carry the post-selected Fredkin result.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Telecom-band heralded Fredkin gate',\n  'foldername':          'teleFredkin',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1,2],\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [3,4,5,6],\n  'removed_connections': [],  \n  'target_quantum':      [\n      '000', '001','010','011',   # c=0, identity\n      '100','110','101','111'    # c=1, swap t\u2081\u2194t\u2082\n  ],\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         30,\n  'samples':             10,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain heralded Fredkin gates for larger photonic circuits.  \n\u2013 Replace one ancilla parity check with a genuine cross-Kerr microresonator for higher success probability.  \n\u2013 Extend to multi-target controlled permutations (higher-order \u201cfan-out\u201d gates).\n\nThis static linear-optical Fredkin gate is the first Pytheus-compatible implementation of a heralded controlled-SWAP for telecom-band qubits, leveraging an abstract Kerr nonlinearity and post-selected ancilla clicks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Heralded three-qubit gates (CNOT, Toffoli, and by simple extension Fredkin) via ancilla-photon parity checks are well-explored in the linear-optics literature. At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol. It fits Pytheus\u2019s toolkit: uses three single-photon emitters, two ancilla photons, a static interferometer, and post-selected click patterns.  \n\nStep 3: Select idea 3.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it generalizes the standard two-qubit parity (Bell) measurement to three qubits, enabling fundamental three-body stabilizer measurements in telecom-band photonics\u2014an essential primitive for future networked purification, syndrome extraction, and multipartite verification.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: only single-photon emitters and ancilla photons, no dynamic feed-forward or hyper-entanglement. \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTelecom-band three-qubit Z-parity-check module via abstract Kerr nonlinearity\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optical network that performs a projective Z\u2297Z\u2297Z measurement on three photonic qubits in the telecom C-band, heralded by a unique two-click signature in two ancilla detectors. Physically, one could implement the joint cross-phase required by the parity check with a Kerr resonator; here we abstract it as a small interferometer mixing the three qubit modes with two ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare qubit modes 0, 1, 2 (nodes A, B, C).  \n \u2022 An ancilla photon pair source feeds modes 3 & 4.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes all five modes.  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on modes 3 & 4 herald parity:  \n    \u2013 Clicks on both {3,4} \u21d2 even parity (states |000\u27e9,|011\u27e9,|101\u27e9,|110\u27e9)  \n    \u2013 Click on exactly one of {3,4} \u21d2 odd parity (states |001\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|100\u27e9,|111\u27e9)  \n \u2022 Qubit\u2010mode outputs (0,1,2) may be routed on or simply measured if needed for downstream tasks.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit parity check',\n  'foldername':            'teleParity3',\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # qubit photons from pair sources\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # or explicit emitters at 0,1,2\n  'num_anc':               2,\n  'anc_detectors':         [3,4],\n  'removed_connections':   [],              # allow all routes into the parity network\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'edges_tried':           30,\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'target_quantum':        [                    # detection patterns on modes [0,1,2,3,4]\n    '***11',  # any 3-qubit basis in even subspace + clicks at 3&4\n    '***10',  # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 3\n    '***01'   # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 4 \n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain these three-body parity modules to measure larger stabilizer codes (surface codes, GHZ\u2010verifications) in C-band photonics.  \n \u2022 Extend to four- and higher-qubit parity checks for multi-body entanglement purification.  \n \u2022 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success rates.\n\nThis primitive unlocks a new class of photonic network protocols\u2014syndrome extraction, multipartite entanglement purification, and networked stabilizer measurements\u2014all in the telecom C-band and ready for an underlying Kerr resonator implementation."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nHeralded entanglement purification via cross-Kerr parity check in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to purify two noisy Bell links\u2014one between Alice & Bob, and one between Bob & Charlie\u2014by performing at Bob a nondestructive even-parity projection on his two qubits. Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal essentially implements the standard parity\u2010check step of Bennett\u2010style entanglement purification (\u201cpurify two noisy Bell pairs by an even\u2010parity projection at the hub\u201d) in the telecom band using an abstracted cross\u2010Kerr/ancilla\u2010photon module. Parity\u2010projection purification is a textbook building block of quantum repeaters and has been studied in detail (both with weak Kerr nonlinearities and with ancilla\u2010photon linear\u2010optical parity gates) dating back to the mid 1990s. There is no new twist beyond porting the known protocol to C-band and recasting it as a small Pytheus routine. This is too close to well-explored schemes and lacks sufficient novelty for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. To be novel, you must go beyond a single parity projection\u2014e.g. embed this in a genuinely new network architecture, introduce coherent superpositions of purification orders, indefinite causal-order purification, or integrate it with another fundamentally new operation rather than just repackaging the textbook gate.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nMerged purification-and-swapping module for telecom-band quantum repeater\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two low-fidelity Bell pairs in the telecom C-band: one pair between Alice (mode A) and Bob (mode B), and another between Bob (mode B\u2032) and Charlie (mode C).  At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes [B\u2032,C]\n\u2013 Linear-optics network at Bob mixing modes B, B\u2032, plus two ancilla inputs\n\u2013 Detectors:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output (A)\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output (C)\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 parity-check ancilla detectors\n   \u2022 Modes 4,5 \u2192 swap-Bell-measurement ancilla detectors\n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,1]] to forbid The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # dealer\u2019s secret\n  'num_anc':      6,                 # four for dealer\u2019s Bell measurements + two for reconstruction\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3],[2,4],[2,5]],  # forbid unwanted cross-links\n  'target_quantum': ['1'],           # herald one photon at output when all clicks succeed\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'edges_tried':  30,\n  'samples':      10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to (k,n) threshold schemes by adding more Bell-pair channels and an n-qubit parity check  \n\u2013 Vary the underlying cross-Kerr strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs  \n\u2013 Switch teleportation order or distribute shares across frequency/time bins  \n\nThis is the first demonstration of a multipartite quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom band, leveraging an abstract Kerr-enabled joint measurement, and opens the door to threshold protocols and networked quantum cryptography.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 2-of-2 quantum secret-sharing scheme proposed here is essentially a straightforward adaptation of the standard Hillery\u2013Bu\u017eek\u2013Berthiaume teleportation\u2010based QSS protocol to the telecom band, with the only twist being an ancilla-photon \u201ccross-Kerr\u201d parity check at reconstruction. Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the use of a quantum switch to superpose two operations is interesting, your proposal merely stitches together the \u201cindefinite-order purification\u201d idea and the \u201centanglement-swap switch\u201d idea that already appear in the ensemble. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed controlled entanglement\u2010swap router is essentially a conditional Fredkin/controlled\u2010SWAP acting on two Bell\u2010pair links\u2014if control=0 you leave A\u2013B and C\u2013D intact; if control=1 you swap B\u2013C to entangle A\u2013D and B\u2013C. This is nothing more than stitching together two well\u2010known primitives (Bell swap + controlled\u2010SWAP) in a static linear\u2010optical network, directly paralleling the ensemble\u2019s \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and \u201cHeralded Spectral\u2010Control Quantum Router via Linear\u2010Optical Controlled\u2010SWAP.\u201d There is no new measurement primitive, causal\u2010order feature, or fundamentally different resource. Hence it does not meet the bar for genuine novelty required for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). To be novel, you need to introduce a truly new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order entanglement router, a non\u2010Hermitian/PT\u2010symmetric routing primitive, or a multi\u2010mode coherent superposition of multiple swap orders\u2014rather than packaging textbook gates in a new wavelength band.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nBidirectional teleportation (\u201cswap\u2010teleportation\u201d) in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe want a single static network that takes two unknown qubits\u2014one at Alice (mode 0) and one at Charlie (mode 5)\u2014and teleports them simultaneously into each other\u2019s arms (Alice\u2019s qubit goes to Charlie, Charlie\u2019s qubit goes to Alice) using only a four-click herald at Bob. Physically a cross-Kerr parity gate could implement the necessary conditional operation, but here we abstract it as a small linear-optical interferometer with ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at modes 0 and 5 (unknown qubits to be swapped).  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2081 emits modes (1,2) linking Alice\u2192Bob.  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2082 emits modes (3,4) linking Bob\u2192Charlie.  \n\u2013 Four ancilla vacuum input modes (6,7,8,9).  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixes modes 1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9 (to be optimized).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on ancilla outputs (detectors at modes 6\u20139).  \n\nHeralding:\nA unique four\u2010click pattern (one click in each ancilla pair) heralds successful simultaneous teleportation. Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This bidirectional or \u201cswap\u2010teleportation\u201d network is functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross\u2010Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits,\u201d merely ported to the telecom C-band. The core primitive\u2014two independent qubits teleported across in one heralded joint measurement\u2014has already been proposed and lacks any new measurement, causal\u2010order twist, or resource. There is no substantive novelty at the PRL level.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol. To be novel, you would need to introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. superposition of multiple swap orders, non-Hermitian or PT\u2010symmetric teleportation steps, higher-dimensional cross-teleportation, or a genuinely new multi-mode measurement primitive beyond the standard butterfly network.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nTelecom-band three-qubit Z-parity-check module via abstract Kerr nonlinearity\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optical network that performs a projective Z\u2297Z\u2297Z measurement on three photonic qubits in the telecom C-band, heralded by a unique two-click signature in two ancilla detectors. Physically, one could implement the joint cross-phase required by the parity check with a Kerr resonator; here we abstract it as a small interferometer mixing the three qubit modes with two ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare qubit modes 0, 1, 2 (nodes A, B, C).  \n \u2022 An ancilla photon pair source feeds modes 3 & 4.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes all five modes.  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on modes 3 & 4 herald parity:  \n    \u2013 Clicks on both {3,4} \u21d2 even parity (states |000\u27e9,|011\u27e9,|101\u27e9,|110\u27e9)  \n    \u2013 Click on exactly one of {3,4} \u21d2 odd parity (states |001\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|100\u27e9,|111\u27e9)  \n \u2022 Qubit\u2010mode outputs (0,1,2) may be routed on or simply measured if needed for downstream tasks.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit parity check',\n  'foldername':            'teleParity3',\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # qubit photons from pair sources\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # or explicit emitters at 0,1,2\n  'num_anc':               2,\n  'anc_detectors':         [3,4],\n  'removed_connections':   [],              # allow all routes into the parity network\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'edges_tried':           30,\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'target_quantum':        [                    # detection patterns on modes [0,1,2,3,4]\n    '***11',  # any 3-qubit basis in even subspace + clicks at 3&4\n    '***10',  # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 3\n    '***01'   # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 4 \n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain these three-body parity modules to measure larger stabilizer codes (surface codes, GHZ\u2010verifications) in C-band photonics.  \n \u2022 Extend to four- and higher-qubit parity checks for multi-body entanglement purification.  \n \u2022 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success rates.\n\nThis primitive unlocks a new class of photonic network protocols\u2014syndrome extraction, multipartite entanglement purification, and networked stabilizer measurements\u2014all in the telecom C-band and ready for an underlying Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: A heralded three\u2010qubit Z\u2297Z\u2297Z parity check via ancilla photons is essentially the same parity\u2010projection primitive already explored in two\u2010 and four\u2010body stabilizer measurements (e.g. the toric\u2010code plaquette readout) and entanglement\u2010purification modules. Simply recasting it as a three\u2010body parity check in the telecom C-band adds no fundamentally new measurement topology, causal\u2010order effect, or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Joint parity measurements of multiple photonic qubits have been demonstrated or proposed (see the four-body toric-code plaquette and two-body purification parity checks). To reach PRL novelty, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014e.g. indefinite-order parity routing, non-Hermitian parity analyzers, or integration into a larger fault-tolerant network primitive\u2014rather than a straightforward three-qubit extension."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router).     "output": "Description:\n3-dimensional \u201cbutterfly\u201d entanglement\u2010routing module in the telecom C-band via abstracted Kerr parity checks\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent 3-dimensional Bell pairs in the telecom C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1 between Alice (mode 0) and Bob \u2081 (mode 1): |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Pair 2 between Charlie (mode 2) and Bob \u2082 (mode 3): |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \nOur goal is to \u201ccross-connect\u201d these links so that at the module\u2019s output Alice (mode 0) becomes entangled with Bob \u2082 (mode 3) in a 3-d Bell state, and Charlie (mode 2) with Bob \u2081 (mode 1).  Physically one envisions using a Kerr nonlinear resonator to implement the required three-dimensional parity checks in the C-band; here we encode that nonlinearity abstractly as a small linear-optical network with ancilla photons and number\u2010resolving detection.\n\nSetup visualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (first 3-d Bell pair)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (second 3-d Bell pair)  \n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] forbids any direct probabilistic source linking Alice\u2194Bob\u2082 or Charlie\u2194Bob\u2081  \n\u2013 Ancilla: 6 vacuum inputs into modes [4\u20139]  \n\u2013 Static interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 1&2 with all ancilla modes  \n\u2013 Number-resolving detectors on ancilla modes [4\u20139] pairs  \n  \u2022 Alice (0) & Bob\u2082 (3): |ii\u27e9 for i=0,1,2  \n  \u2022 Charlie (2) & Bob\u2081 (1): |jj\u27e9 for j=0,1,2  \n\nIn the computational basis on modes [0,1,2,3], the 9 non-zero terms are:\n  ['0000','0110','0220',\n   '1001','1111','1221',\n   '2002','2112','2222']\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band 3d butterfly entanglement Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. Physically the local operations at the repeater nodes would exploit Kerr nonlinearity, but Pytheus just sees two sequential parity projections and a final Bell-swap measurement.\n\n  C) A measurement-based CZ gate between two remote telecom-band qubits using a small entanglement-resource and a single cross-Kerr-enabled parity check. Abstractly this is a teleportation of a CZ gate: Bob performs a joint parity check on one qubit from each resource pair, projecting onto an even/odd subspace and thereby enacting a non-local CZ between Alice and Charlie.\n\nStep 2: Novelty check and Pytheus obstacles:\n\n  A) Novel because past experiments cover only plain entanglement swapping and gates, not purification.
