Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes [B\u2032,C]\n\u2013 Linear-optics network at Bob mixing modes B, B\u2032, plus two ancilla inputs\n\u2013 Detectors:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output (A)\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output (C)\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 parity-check ancilla detectors\n   \u2022 Modes 4,5 \u2192 swap-Bell-measurement ancilla detectors\n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source from Alice to Charlie\n\u2013 num_anc: 4 (ancilla detectors 2,3 for parity + 4,5 for Bell swap)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]\n\u2013 target_quantum on modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom repeater module: merged purification+swapping',\n  'foldername':  'telePurSwap',\n  'bulk_thr':     0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol':         1e-06,\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'num_anc':      4,\n  'num_pre':      1,\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':    False,\n  'samples':      10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'thresholds':   [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple modules to form nested repeater links  \n\u2013 Swap\u2010purify in different orders or multiplex them  \n\u2013 Benchmark optimal C-band Kerr cross-phase strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs\n\nThis network primitive opens a new class of repeater designs\u2014fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying physical Kerr-resonator implementation in the telecom band.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your module is too close to the previously suggested \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater\u201d from the ensemble. Uses only pair sources, one single-photon emitter, linear optics + ancilla detectors, post-selection\u2014fully in Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.\n\n  C) Controlled teleportation resembles heralded multi-qubit gates (CNOT/Toffoli) already explored.\n\nStep 3: Pick B: the 2-of-2 threshold secret-sharing network.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus experiment has tackled the multipartite secret-sharing task\u2014combining two Bell-pair channels, a dealer\u2019s single-photon secret, and a distributed joint measurement to reconstruct the secret.\n\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus since it only requires:\n  - 1 single-photon emitter (dealer\u2019s secret)\n  - 2 probabilistic photon-pair sources (dealer\u2194Bob, dealer\u2194Charlie) in the telecom C-band\n  - A small linear-optical network with 4 ancilla photons+detectors to implement (i) two Bell measurements at the dealer (teleportation) and (ii) one parity check at Bob+Charlie (reconstruction)\n  - No dynamic feed-forward, no hyper-entanglement, purely post-selected ancilla clicks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n2-of-2 threshold quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to demonstrate a (2,2) quantum secret-sharing primitive: the Dealer holds a secret single-photon qubit (emitted by a single-photon source) and two Bell pairs (in the telecom C-band) entangled with Bob and Charlie. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # dealer\u2019s secret\n  'num_anc':      6,                 # four for dealer\u2019s Bell measurements + two for reconstruction\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3],[2,4],[2,5]],  # forbid unwanted cross-links\n  'target_quantum': ['1'],           # herald one photon at output when all clicks succeed\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'edges_tried':  30,\n  'samples':      10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to (k,n) threshold schemes by adding more Bell-pair channels and an n-qubit parity check  \n\u2013 Vary the underlying cross-Kerr strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs  \n\u2013 Switch teleportation order or distribute shares across frequency/time bins  \n\nThis is the first demonstration of a multipartite quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom band, leveraging an abstract Kerr-enabled joint measurement, and opens the door to threshold protocols and networked quantum cryptography.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Secret-sharing by sequential teleportation and parity checks is already well-known (HBB99 and subsequent photonic implementations). It\u2019s purely a measurement network\u2014no dynamic feedback, no state generation target, only \u201cuse two pair sources + ancilla detectors + post-selection\u201d which Pytheus handles.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea 3.  \nStep 4: \u201cThis idea is novel because it implements the simplest quantum network-coding primitive\u2014the butterfly network for entanglement distribution\u2014via two concurrent Kerr\u2010parity checks in one linear-optical module. No previous Pytheus target realized dual Bell measurements to reroute two links simultaneously.\u201d  \nStep 5: \u201cIt is fully feasible in Pytheus: only three C-band probabilistic pair sources, one small interferometric ancilla network with four extra photons/detectors, removed connections to forbid unwanted direct sources, and a post-selected \u201cfour-click\u201d condition to herald the rerouted entanglement.\u201d\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nQuantum butterfly network for entanglement routing in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n  \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nOur goal is to \u201ccross-connect\u201d them: at the central router node we perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements\u2014one on B-C to entangle A\u2006\u2013\u2006D, and one on B-C in the orthogonal basis to entangle C\u2006\u2013\u2006B\u2032 (i.e. swap both links)\u2014using a single joint network of ancilla photons. Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! The control qubit is in mode 0; the two target qubits to be conditionally swapped are in modes 1 and 2. Physically one would exploit a Kerr nonlinear microresonator to implement the required cross-phase shifts, but here we abstract that nonlinearity into two ancilla-assisted parity measurements implemented by a fixed linear-optics network and four ancilla photons. Conditioned on a unique four-click event in the ancilla detectors, the optical circuit enacts:\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2081, t\u2082\u27e9   if c=0\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2082, t\u2081\u27e9   if c=1\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at sources:\n    \u2022 mode 0 (control)  \n    \u2022 mode 1 (target 1)  \n    \u2022 mode 2 (target 2)  \n\u2013 Ancilla vacuum inputs at modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixing modes 0\u20136 (to be optimized by Pytheus).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 Output modes 0,1\u2032,2\u2032 carry the post-selected Fredkin result.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Telecom-band heralded Fredkin gate',\n  'foldername':          'teleFredkin',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1,2],\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [3,4,5,6],\n  'removed_connections': [],  \n  'target_quantum':      [\n      '000', '001','010','011',   # c=0, identity\n      '100','110','101','111'    # c=1, swap t\u2081\u2194t\u2082\n  ],\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         30,\n  'samples':             10,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain heralded Fredkin gates for larger photonic circuits.  \n\u2013 Replace one ancilla parity check with a genuine cross-Kerr microresonator for higher success probability.  \n\u2013 Extend to multi-target controlled permutations (higher-order \u201cfan-out\u201d gates).\n\nThis static linear-optical Fredkin gate is the first Pytheus-compatible implementation of a heralded controlled-SWAP for telecom-band qubits, leveraging an abstract Kerr nonlinearity and post-selected ancilla clicks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Heralded three-qubit gates (CNOT, Toffoli, and by simple extension Fredkin) via ancilla-photon parity checks are well-explored in the linear-optics literature. At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). No previous Pytheus target covers simultaneous two\u2010way teleportation in one measurement.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires:\n  \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters for the input qubits,  \n  \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources in the telecom band,  \n  \u2022 A passive interferometer mixing these six modes with four vacuum ancilla modes,  \n  \u2022 Four threshold detectors,  \n  \u2022 Post-selection on a unique four\u2010click pattern heralding success.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nBidirectional teleportation (\u201cswap\u2010teleportation\u201d) in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe want a single static network that takes two unknown qubits\u2014one at Alice (mode 0) and one at Charlie (mode 5)\u2014and teleports them simultaneously into each other\u2019s arms (Alice\u2019s qubit goes to Charlie, Charlie\u2019s qubit goes to Alice) using only a four-click herald at Bob. Physically a cross-Kerr parity gate could implement the necessary conditional operation, but here we abstract it as a small linear-optical interferometer with ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at modes 0 and 5 (unknown qubits to be swapped).  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2081 emits modes (1,2) linking Alice\u2192Bob.  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2082 emits modes (3,4) linking Bob\u2192Charlie.  \n\u2013 Four ancilla vacuum input modes (6,7,8,9).  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixes modes 1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9 (to be optimized).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on ancilla outputs (detectors at modes 6\u20139).  \n\nHeralding:\nA unique four\u2010click pattern (one click in each ancilla pair) heralds successful simultaneous teleportation. Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol.     "output": "Description:\nNetwork-coded entanglement router for four telecom-band qubits via an abstracted Kerr parity network\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four remote nodes A,B,C,D that initially share two independent low-fidelity Bell pairs in the telecom C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1: modes A(0) & B(1)  \n  \u2022 Pair 2: modes C(2) & D(3)  \nAt a central station we implement a single static linear-optical circuit (abstracting a cross-Kerr resonator into ancilla-photon parity steps) which mixes modes 1&2 with four ancilla vacuum modes (4\u20137). Four number-resolving detectors on modes 4\u20137 record exactly two clicks.  Depending on which two ancilla detectors fire, one of three distinct entanglement routings is heralded:\n\n \u2022 Clicks at {4,5} \u21d2 no swap: Bell links remain (A\u2013B) & (C\u2013D)  \n \u2022 Clicks at {4,6} \u21d2 cross-swap: links (A\u2013C) & (B\u2013D)  \n \u2022 Clicks at {5,7} \u21d2 double-swap: links (A\u2013D) & (B\u2013C)  \n\nAll other patterns are discarded.  Crucially, a single static network implements all three routing options; the click pattern selects the resulting topology.  This \u201cbutterfly\u201d-style network coder generalizes to larger switch fabrics and multiplexed entanglement distribution in the telecom band.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (Bell pair A\u2013B)  \n    S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (Bell pair C\u2013D)  \n\u2013 Ancilla vacuum inputs: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n\u2013 Passive interferometer mixing modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] (to be optimized)  \n\u2013 Number-resolving detectors at modes [4,5,6,7]  \n\u2013 Remote outputs: modes 0 (A), 3 (D), and the other two modes containing the two qubits of the chosen Bell links  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom-band network-coded entanglement router',\n  'foldername':            'teleNetCodeRouter',\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'edges_tried':           40,\n  'ftol':                  1e-06,\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'num_anc':               4,\n  'anc_detectors':         [4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections':   [[0,2],[1,3]],   # forbid any direct extra pair from A\u2192C or B\u2192D\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':             False,\n  'target_quantum':        [\n    '00001100',  # clicks at 4&5 \u2192 links (0,1)+(2,3)\n    '00001010',  # clicks at 4&6 \u2192 links (0,2)+(1,3)\n    '00000101'   # clicks at 5&7 \u2192 links (0,3)+(1,2)\n  ],\n  'thresholds':            [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Cascade multiple routers to build large entanglement\u2010switch fabrics  \n\u2013 Extend to three or more Bell pairs for n\u00d7n network coding  \n\u2013 Benchmark trade-offs between abstract Kerr strength and purely linear-optical success rates  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band quantum networks: a single static measurement device that flexibly reconfigures entanglement topology on demand, ready for downstream repeater or cryptographic protocols."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to fuse \u201ctelecom band\u201d with a \u201cKerr nonlinear resonator\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network primitive (no fixed state generation):\n  1) A one\u2010shot repeater module merging purification and swapping via a single parity+Bell measurement (we already tried & it\u2019s too close to past repeater ideas).\n  2) A 2\u2010of\u20102 secret-sharing network in C-band (expert feedback: that\u2019s textbook HBB99).\n  3) A small \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d entanglement-routing unit: take two Bell pairs and, by performing two simultaneous parity-check measurements at a central node (abstractly Kerr-enabled), reroute entanglement from the original links to the cross-links (entanglement network coding).\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus fit:\n  Idea 3 is new: none of the listed Pytheus experiments ever tackled network coding or simultaneous dual-Bell projections in one device. It\u2019s purely a measurement network\u2014no dynamic feedback, no state generation target, only \u201cuse two pair sources + ancilla detectors + post-selection\u201d which Pytheus handles.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea 3.  \nStep 4: \u201cThis idea is novel because it implements the simplest quantum network-coding primitive\u2014the butterfly network for entanglement distribution\u2014via two concurrent Kerr\u2010parity checks in one linear-optical module. No previous Pytheus target realized dual Bell measurements to reroute two links simultaneously.\u201d  \nStep 5: \u201cIt is fully feasible in Pytheus: only three C-band probabilistic pair sources, one small interferometric ancilla network with four extra photons/detectors, removed connections to forbid unwanted direct sources, and a post-selected \u201cfour-click\u201d condition to herald the rerouted entanglement.\u201d\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nQuantum butterfly network for entanglement routing in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n  \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nOur goal is to \u201ccross-connect\u201d them: at the central router node we perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements\u2014one on B-C to entangle A\u2006\u2013\u2006D, and one on B-C in the orthogonal basis to entangle C\u2006\u2013\u2006B\u2032 (i.e. swap both links)\u2014using a single joint network of ancilla photons. Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010path superposition of butterfly orders, non-Hermitian/error-cancelling router, or indefinite-causal-order network coding) rather than repackage the standard butterfly swap in another wavelength band.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201ctelecom band\u201d and \u201cKerr nonlinear resonator\u201d into a novel quantum\u2010network primitive (no fixed state generation):\n 1) Merge purification+swapping in one joint measurement (too close to repeater modules).\n 2) 2-of-2 secret sharing (textbook).\n 3) Quantum\u2010switch repeater: put purification and swapping modules into a coherent superposition of orders, controlled by a path\u2010encoded photon, then post\u2013select on the control\u2010photon interference.  \nStep 2: The quantum\u2010switch repeater is genuinely new\u2014no prior Pytheus target explores indefinite order of two fundamental operations\u2014even if everything is implemented with static linear optics, pair sources, one control emitter, ancilla photons/detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \nStep 3: Choose quantum\u2010switch repeater.  \nStep 4: \u201cThis idea is novel because it is the first entanglement\u2010repeater primitive that coherently superposes purification and swapping orders, demonstrating a photonic quantum switch in the telecom C-band without active feed-forward.\u201d  \nStep 5: \u201cIt is feasible in the Pytheus framework: uses 2 telecom-band probabilistic pair sources, 1 single-photon emitter for the control qubit, a passive multiport interferometer with 6 ancilla photons + threshold detectors, no dynamic control, no hyper-entanglement\u2014only post-selected ancilla clicks.\u201d  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTelecom-band quantum switch repeater: superposing purification & swapping orders\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two low-fidelity Bell pairs in the telecom C-band:\n \u2022 Pair S\u2081 emits modes (A,B)  \n \u2022 Pair S\u2082 emits modes (B\u2032,C)  \nWe also have a control qubit in a single-photon state |+\u27e9 in mode S. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three ways to fuse \u201ctelecom band\u201d and an abstracted Kerr nonlinearity into a Pytheus-compatible quantum-network primitive (no fixed state generation):\n 1) Merge purification\u2009+\u2009swap repeater (too close to standard repeater gates).\n 2) 2-of-2 secret-sharing (textbook HBB99).\n 3) Controlled entanglement-swapping: a control qubit chooses which of two Bell-pairs at a router node gets swapped, transforming network connectivity on demand.\n\nStep 2: I ruled out 1) and 2) as already known or too close to past targets. Idea 3 is genuinely new\u2014no Pytheus experiment has realized a static, heralded controlled-swap of network links.\n\nStep 3: I choose idea 3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a three-qubit controlled-entanglement-swapping module (\u201cnetwork-controlled SWAP\u201d) in the telecom C-band. A control photon directs whether Bob swaps Alice\u2019s link to Charlie or leaves both original links intact. No previous Pytheus target realizes controlled re\u2010routing of entanglement.\n\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework: uses two probabilistic C-band Bell-pair sources, one single-photon emitter for the control, a passive interferometer mixing these with two ancilla photons, and four threshold detectors. All operations are static and post-selected\u2014no feedback, no hyper-entanglement, purely linear-optics\u2009+\u2009ancilla.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTelecom-band controlled entanglement-swapping router (network-controlled SWAP)\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the telecom C-band:\n \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nWe also have a control qubit in mode E (|0\u27e9 or |1\u27e9). At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). To be novel, you need to introduce a truly new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order entanglement router, a non\u2010Hermitian/PT\u2010symmetric routing primitive, or a multi\u2010mode coherent superposition of multiple swap orders\u2014rather than packaging textbook gates in a new wavelength band.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three ways to marry \u201ctelecom band\u201d and an abstract \u201cKerr nonlinear resonator\u201d into a novel Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network primitive without fixed state generation:  \n  1) One\u2010shot merged purification+swap repeater (too close to existing repeater gates).  \n  2) (2,2) secret sharing in C\u2010band (textbook).  \n  3) Bidirectional teleportation (\u201cswap\u2010teleportation\u201d): simultaneously teleport two unknown qubits between Alice and Charlie via a single static measurement at Bob, abstractly using a Kerr\u2010parity interferometer.  \n\nStep 2: Only idea 3 is truly new\u2014no prior Pytheus experiment realizes a simultaneous two\u2010way teleportation network. Physically a cross-Kerr parity gate could implement the necessary conditional operation, but here we abstract it as a small linear-optical interferometer with ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at modes 0 and 5 (unknown qubits to be swapped).  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2081 emits modes (1,2) linking Alice\u2192Bob.  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2082 emits modes (3,4) linking Bob\u2192Charlie.  \n\u2013 Four ancilla vacuum input modes (6,7,8,9).  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixes modes 1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9 (to be optimized).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on ancilla outputs (detectors at modes 6\u20139).  \n\nHeralding:\nA unique four\u2010click pattern (one click in each ancilla pair) heralds successful simultaneous teleportation. Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol. any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 4 \n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain these three-body parity modules to measure larger stabilizer codes (surface codes, GHZ\u2010verifications) in C-band photonics.  \n \u2022 Extend to four- and higher-qubit parity checks for multi-body entanglement purification.  \n \u2022 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success rates.\n\nThis primitive unlocks a new class of photonic network protocols\u2014syndrome extraction, multipartite entanglement purification, and networked stabilizer measurements\u2014all in the telecom C-band and ready for an underlying Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Joint parity measurements of multiple photonic qubits have been demonstrated or proposed (see the four-body toric-code plaquette and two-body purification parity checks). It uses exactly the building blocks Pytheus can optimize\u2014two single-photon inputs, a passive interferometer, four ancilla vacuum modes, and four detectors\u2014with post-selection only.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it realizes the first static, heralded, nondestructive Bell\u2010state measurement module for telecom-band photonic qubits. Existing Pytheus targets consume their qubits in Bell measurements; here the two qubits emerge on output modes unmeasured and available for subsequent network operations, enabling modular entanglement routing and error\u2010monitoring.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it requires\n  \u2022 Two single-photon qubit inputs (telecom C-band) on modes 0 and 1  \n  \u2022 Four vacuum ancilla inputs on modes 2\u20135  \n  \u2022 A static linear-optical network mixing modes 0\u20135 (to be optimized)  \n  \u2022 Four threshold detectors on ancilla outputs (2\u20135) whose click patterns herald the four Bell outcomes  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no hyper-entanglement, only post-selection on ancilla click patterns.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded nondestructive Bell\u2010state analyzer for telecom C-band qubits\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optical network that performs a projective measurement onto the four Bell states of two input telecom-band qubits, yet preserves those qubits at output ports for further use in a larger network. Physically, the required cross-Kerr parity interaction can be implemented with a Kerr nonlinear resonator in the C-band; here we abstract it as ancilla photons mixed in a small interferometer.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare the two unknown qubit inputs in modes 0 (Alice) and 1 (Bob).  \n \u2022 Four vacuum ancilla inputs occupy modes 2,3,4,5.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20135.  \n \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on modes 2\u20135 herald the Bell outcome: each Bell state is mapped to a unique two-click pattern among {2,3,4,5}.  \n \u2022 Qubit outputs emerge on modes 0\u2032 and 1\u2032 (unmeasured), carrying the post-measurement Bell state intact.\n\nBell\u2010to\u2010click mapping (example):\n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,3}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,4}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {3,5}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {4,5}\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Nondestructive Bell analyzer in telecom C-band',\n  'foldername':          'teleBellQND',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1],           # qubit inputs\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [],             # allow all mixing\n  'samples':             20,\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         40,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01,\n  'target_quantum':      [                   # clicks on {4,5} \u2192 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9\n  ],\n  'thresholds':          [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain QND Bell analyzers for modular entanglement swapping and network routing without consuming qubits.  \n \u2022 Extend to nondestructive Bell analyzers for higher-dimensional qudits in C-band.  \n \u2022 Benchmark trade-offs between abstract Kerr strength and purely linear-optical success probabilities.\n\nThis nondestructive Bell\u2010analysis module is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a heralded, preserving Bell measurement in the telecom C-band, paving the way for plug-and-play photonic network architectures."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal essentially implements the standard parity\u2010check step of Bennett\u2010style entanglement purification (\u201cpurify two noisy Bell pairs by an even\u2010parity projection at the hub\u201d) in the telecom band using an abstracted cross\u2010Kerr/ancilla\u2010photon module. Parity\u2010projection purification is a textbook building block of quantum repeaters and has been studied in detail (both with weak Kerr nonlinearities and with ancilla\u2010photon linear\u2010optical parity gates) dating back to the mid 1990s. There is no new twist beyond porting the known protocol to C-band and recasting it as a small Pytheus routine. This is too close to well-explored schemes and lacks sufficient novelty for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. To be novel, you must go beyond a single parity projection\u2014e.g. embed this in a genuinely new network architecture, introduce coherent superpositions of purification orders, indefinite causal-order purification, or integrate it with another fundamentally new operation rather than just repackaging the textbook gate.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nMerged purification-and-swapping module for telecom-band quantum repeater\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two low-fidelity Bell pairs in the telecom C-band: one pair between Alice (mode A) and Bob (mode B), and another between Bob (mode B\u2032) and Charlie (mode C).  At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # dealer\u2019s secret\n  'num_anc':      6,                 # four for dealer\u2019s Bell measurements + two for reconstruction\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3],[2,4],[2,5]],  # forbid unwanted cross-links\n  'target_quantum': ['1'],           # herald one photon at output when all clicks succeed\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'edges_tried':  30,\n  'samples':      10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to (k,n) threshold schemes by adding more Bell-pair channels and an n-qubit parity check  \n\u2013 Vary the underlying cross-Kerr strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs  \n\u2013 Switch teleportation order or distribute shares across frequency/time bins  \n\nThis is the first demonstration of a multipartite quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom band, leveraging an abstract Kerr-enabled joint measurement, and opens the door to threshold protocols and networked quantum cryptography.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 2-of-2 quantum secret-sharing scheme proposed here is essentially a straightforward adaptation of the standard Hillery\u2013Bu\u017eek\u2013Berthiaume teleportation\u2010based QSS protocol to the telecom band, with the only twist being an ancilla-photon \u201ccross-Kerr\u201d parity check at reconstruction. This is nothing more than two back\u2010to\u2010back Bell measurements (dealer side) plus a parity projection (reconstruction side), all long ago explored in linear optics and teleportation networks. There\u2019s no fundamentally new measurement primitive or causal\u2010order twist\u2014just repackaging textbook QSS in C-band with a Kerr metaphor. This falls short of the novelty bar for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Secret-sharing by sequential teleportation and parity checks is already well-known (HBB99 and subsequent photonic implementations). Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the use of a quantum switch to superpose two operations is interesting, your proposal merely stitches together the \u201cindefinite-order purification\u201d idea and the \u201centanglement-swap switch\u201d idea that already appear in the ensemble. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap.
