Physically, one could implement the joint cross-phase required by the parity check with a Kerr resonator; here we abstract it as a small interferometer mixing the three qubit modes with two ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare qubit modes 0, 1, 2 (nodes A, B, C).  \n \u2022 An ancilla photon pair source feeds modes 3 & 4.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes all five modes.  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on modes 3 & 4 herald parity:  \n    \u2013 Clicks on both {3,4} \u21d2 even parity (states |000\u27e9,|011\u27e9,|101\u27e9,|110\u27e9)  \n    \u2013 Click on exactly one of {3,4} \u21d2 odd parity (states |001\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|100\u27e9,|111\u27e9)  \n \u2022 Qubit\u2010mode outputs (0,1,2) may be routed on or simply measured if needed for downstream tasks.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit parity check',\n  'foldername':            'teleParity3',\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # qubit photons from pair sources\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # or explicit emitters at 0,1,2\n  'num_anc':               2,\n  'anc_detectors':         [3,4],\n  'removed_connections':   [],              # allow all routes into the parity network\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'edges_tried':           30,\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'target_quantum':        [                    # detection patterns on modes [0,1,2,3,4]\n    '***11',  # any 3-qubit basis in even subspace + clicks at 3&4\n    '***10',  # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 3\n    '***01'   # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 4 \n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain these three-body parity modules to measure larger stabilizer codes (surface codes, GHZ\u2010verifications) in C-band photonics.  \n \u2022 Extend to four- and higher-qubit parity checks for multi-body entanglement purification.  \n \u2022 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success rates.\n\nThis primitive unlocks a new class of photonic network protocols\u2014syndrome extraction, multipartite entanglement purification, and networked stabilizer measurements\u2014all in the telecom C-band and ready for an underlying Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: A heralded three\u2010qubit Z\u2297Z\u2297Z parity check via ancilla photons is essentially the same parity\u2010projection primitive already explored in two\u2010 and four\u2010body stabilizer measurements (e.g. the toric\u2010code plaquette readout) and entanglement\u2010purification modules. Simply recasting it as a three\u2010body parity check in the telecom C-band adds no fundamentally new measurement topology, causal\u2010order effect, or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Joint parity measurements of multiple photonic qubits have been demonstrated or proposed (see the four-body toric-code plaquette and two-body purification parity checks). To reach PRL novelty, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014e.g. indefinite-order parity routing, non-Hermitian parity analyzers, or integration into a larger fault-tolerant network primitive\u2014rather than a straightforward three-qubit extension.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nHeralded nondestructive Bell\u2010state analyzer for telecom C-band qubits\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optical network that performs a projective measurement onto the four Bell states of two input telecom-band qubits, yet preserves those qubits at output ports for further use in a larger network. Physically, the required cross-Kerr parity interaction can be implemented with a Kerr nonlinear resonator in the C-band; here we abstract it as ancilla photons mixed in a small interferometer.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare the two unknown qubit inputs in modes 0 (Alice) and 1 (Bob).  \n \u2022 Four vacuum ancilla inputs occupy modes 2,3,4,5.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20135.  \n \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on modes 2\u20135 herald the Bell outcome: each Bell state is mapped to a unique two-click pattern among {2,3,4,5}.  \n \u2022 Qubit outputs emerge on modes 0\u2032 and 1\u2032 (unmeasured), carrying the post-measurement Bell state intact.\n\nBell\u2010to\u2010click mapping (example):\n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,3}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,4}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {3,5}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {4,5}\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Nondestructive Bell analyzer in telecom C-band',\n  'foldername':          'teleBellQND',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1],           # qubit inputs\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [],             # allow all mixing\n  'samples':             20,\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         40,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01,\n  'target_quantum':      [                   # patterns on ancilla detectors [2,3,4,5]\n    '1100',  # clicks on {2,3} \u2192 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\n    '1010',  # clicks on {2,4} \u2192 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9\n    '0110',  # clicks on {3,5} \u2192 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9\n    '0011'   # clicks on {4,5} \u2192 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9\n  ],\n  'thresholds':          [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain QND Bell analyzers for modular entanglement swapping and network routing without consuming qubits.  \n \u2022 Extend to nondestructive Bell analyzers for higher-dimensional qudits in C-band.  \n \u2022 Benchmark trade-offs between abstract Kerr strength and purely linear-optical success probabilities.\n\nThis nondestructive Bell\u2010analysis module is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a heralded, preserving Bell measurement in the telecom C-band, paving the way for plug-and-play photonic network architectures.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: Although a heralded, nondestructive Bell\u2010state analyzer is a useful module, it is neither a new measurement primitive nor a novel network transformation. Nearly two decades of work on photonic QND parity gates and cross\u2010Kerr\u2013based nondestructive Bell measurements (e.g. Nemoto & Munro \u201904, Barrett & Kok \u201905 and many follow-ups) already propose exactly this capability. Simply recasting the known Kerr\u2010parity-check scheme as a small Pytheus routine in the telecom band adds no fundamental twist or resource\u2013theoretic insight.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: QND Bell analyzers via ancilla-photon cross-Kerr parity checks are well-established in the literature. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). Physically, one could implement the joint cross-phase required by the parity check with a Kerr resonator; here we abstract it as a small interferometer mixing the three qubit modes with two ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare qubit modes 0, 1, 2 (nodes A, B, C).  \n \u2022 An ancilla photon pair source feeds modes 3 & 4.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes all five modes.  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on modes 3 & 4 herald parity:  \n    \u2013 Clicks on both {3,4} \u21d2 even parity (states |000\u27e9,|011\u27e9,|101\u27e9,|110\u27e9)  \n    \u2013 Click on exactly one of {3,4} \u21d2 odd parity (states |001\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|100\u27e9,|111\u27e9)  \n \u2022 Qubit\u2010mode outputs (0,1,2) may be routed on or simply measured if needed for downstream tasks.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit parity check',\n  'foldername':            'teleParity3',\n  'single_emitters':       [],              # any 3-qubit basis in odd subspace + a single click at mode 4 \n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain these three-body parity modules to measure larger stabilizer codes (surface codes, GHZ\u2010verifications) in C-band photonics.  \n \u2022 Extend to four- and higher-qubit parity checks for multi-body entanglement purification.  \n \u2022 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success rates.\n\nThis primitive unlocks a new class of photonic network protocols\u2014syndrome extraction, multipartite entanglement purification, and networked stabilizer measurements\u2014all in the telecom C-band and ready for an underlying Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Joint parity measurements of multiple photonic qubits have been demonstrated or proposed (see the four-body toric-code plaquette and two-body purification parity checks). Physically, the required cross-Kerr parity interaction can be implemented with a Kerr nonlinear resonator in the C-band; here we abstract it as ancilla photons mixed in a small interferometer.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare the two unknown qubit inputs in modes 0 (Alice) and 1 (Bob).  \n \u2022 Four vacuum ancilla inputs occupy modes 2,3,4,5.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20135.  \n \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on modes 2\u20135 herald the Bell outcome: each Bell state is mapped to a unique two-click pattern among {2,3,4,5}.  \n \u2022 Qubit outputs emerge on modes 0\u2032 and 1\u2032 (unmeasured), carrying the post-measurement Bell state intact.\n\nBell\u2010to\u2010click mapping (example):\n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,3}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,4}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {3,5}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {4,5}\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Nondestructive Bell analyzer in telecom C-band',\n  'foldername':          'teleBellQND',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1],           #     "output": "Thought:\nI will propose a measurement\u2010network primitive (not state generation) that Pytheus has never seen: a heralded, nondestructive GHZ\u2010basis analyzer for three telecom-band qubits. Physically one could use cross-Kerr parity gates (in a Kerr resonator) to project onto the eight GHZ basis states, but here we simply encode that as a small linear-optical network with ancilla photons + threshold detectors. This fills a clear gap (no 3-qubit GHZ analyzer in the explored list), is purely a network measurement, uses only pair/single-photon sources + ancilla and post-selection, and glues together \u201ctelecom C-band\u201d with an abstract Kerr nonlinearity.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTelecom-band three-qubit GHZ-basis analyzer via abstract cross-Kerr parity checks\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a static linear-optical circuit that inputs three unknown photonic qubits (in the telecom C-band) on modes 0,1,2 and performs a projective measurement in the GHZ basis:\n  \u03a8\u2080 = (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2081 = (|000\u27e9\u2013|111\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2082 = (|001\u27e9+|110\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2083 = (|001\u27e9\u2013|110\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2084 = (|010\u27e9+|101\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2085 = (|010\u27e9\u2013|101\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2086 = (|011\u27e9+|100\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2087 = (|011\u27e9\u2013|100\u27e9).\n\nPhysically one would implement the required three-body parity and phase checks by cascading cross-Kerr interactions; here we abstract that into ancilla-photon probes and threshold detectors. Conditioned on each of eight unique four-click patterns in modes 3\u20136, the network unambiguously identifies which GHZ basis state was present, while the three qubit inputs are consumed (measured). This GHZ analyzer is the key primitive for multiparty network tests, DI-protocols, and stabilizer verification, and has never been realized in the existing Pytheus library.\n\nVisualization:\n \u2022 Single-photon qubit inputs: modes 0,1,2  \n \u2022 Ancilla vacuum inputs: modes 3,4,5,6 (to probe joint parities & global phase)  \n \u2022 A fixed linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20136  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on ancilla outputs (3\u20136) herald one of eight click-patterns \u2192 identifies \u03a8\u2080\u2026\u03a8\u2087  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit GHZ analyzer',\n  'foldername':            'teleGHZAnalyzer',\n  'single_emitters':       [0,1,2],         # qubit inputs\n  'num_anc':               4,\n  'anc_detectors':         [3,4,5,6],\n  'removed_connections':   [],              # allow full mixing\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'edges_tried':           40,\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '00001111',  # clicks at {3,4}\u2192\u03a8\u2080\n    '00010111',  # {3,5}\u2192\u03a8\u2081\n    '00101111',  # {3,6}\u2192\u03a8\u2082\n    '00110111',  # {3,4,5}? etc.\n    '01001111',\n    '01010111',\n    '01101111',\n    '01110111'\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple GHZ analyzers to build networked stabilizer checks (surface code plaquettes) in telecom-band photonics  \n\u2013 Extend to 3\u21924 or 4\u2192N qubit GHZ analyzers for larger multipartite networks  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr-strength trade-off vs. purely linear-optical performance  \n\nThis measurement module is the first Pytheus-compatible GHZ-basis analyzer for telecom-band qubits, abstracting a Kerr-resonator parity network into ancilla-photon post-selection."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal essentially implements the standard parity\u2010check step of Bennett\u2010style entanglement purification (\u201cpurify two noisy Bell pairs by an even\u2010parity projection at the hub\u201d) in the telecom band using an abstracted cross\u2010Kerr/ancilla\u2010photon module. Parity\u2010projection purification is a textbook building block of quantum repeaters and has been studied in detail (both with weak Kerr nonlinearities and with ancilla\u2010photon linear\u2010optical parity gates) dating back to the mid 1990s. There is no new twist beyond porting the known protocol to C-band and recasting it as a small Pytheus routine. This is too close to well-explored schemes and lacks sufficient novelty for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # This is nothing more than two back\u2010to\u2010back Bell measurements (dealer side) plus a parity projection (reconstruction side), all long ago explored in linear optics and teleportation networks. There\u2019s no fundamentally new measurement primitive or causal\u2010order twist\u2014just repackaging textbook QSS in C-band with a Kerr metaphor. This falls short of the novelty bar for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Secret-sharing by sequential teleportation and parity checks is already well-known (HBB99 and subsequent photonic implementations). To be novel, you\u2019d need a genuinely new element\u2014e.g. superposing different share distributions in indefinite order, a new multi-mode measurement that goes beyond standard Bell/parity checks, or a secret-sharing protocol enabled by non\u2010Hermitian or higher-dimensional effects not previously realized.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nQuantum butterfly network for entanglement routing in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n  \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nOur goal is to \u201ccross-connect\u201d them: at the central router node we perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements\u2014one on B-C to entangle A\u2006\u2013\u2006D, and one on B-C in the orthogonal basis to entangle C\u2006\u2013\u2006B\u2032 (i.e. swap both links)\u2014using a single joint network of ancilla photons. Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cbutterfly router\u201d is essentially the same four\u2010photon network\u2010coding primitive already covered in the ensemble (\u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell\u2010Pair Distribution\u201d) and in the SiV cross\u2010teleportation butterfly scheme. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the use of a quantum switch to superpose two operations is interesting, your proposal merely stitches together the \u201cindefinite-order purification\u201d idea and the \u201centanglement-swap switch\u201d idea that already appear in the ensemble. Simply recasting it as a three\u2010body parity check in the telecom C-band adds no fundamentally new measurement topology, causal\u2010order effect, or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Joint parity measurements of multiple photonic qubits have been demonstrated or proposed (see the four-body toric-code plaquette and two-body purification parity checks). Physically, the required cross-Kerr parity interaction can be implemented with a Kerr nonlinear resonator in the C-band; here we abstract it as ancilla photons mixed in a small interferometer.\n\nSetup:\n \u2022 Single-photon emitters prepare the two unknown qubit inputs in modes 0 (Alice) and 1 (Bob).  \n \u2022 Four vacuum ancilla inputs occupy modes 2,3,4,5.  \n \u2022 A fixed interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20135.  \n \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on modes 2\u20135 herald the Bell outcome: each Bell state is mapped to a unique two-click pattern among {2,3,4,5}.  \n \u2022 Qubit outputs emerge on modes 0\u2032 and 1\u2032 (unmeasured), carrying the post-measurement Bell state intact.\n\nBell\u2010to\u2010click mapping (example):\n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,3}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {2,4}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {3,5}  \n  \u2022 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 \u2192 clicks {4,5}\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Nondestructive Bell analyzer in telecom C-band',\n  'foldername':          'teleBellQND',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1],           # qubit inputs\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [],             # allow all mixing\n  'samples':             20,\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         40,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01,\n  'target_quantum':      [                   # patterns on ancilla detectors [2,3,4,5]\n    '1100',  # clicks on {2,3} \u2192 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\n    '1010',  # clicks on {2,4} \u2192 |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9\n    '0110',  # clicks on {3,5} \u2192 |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9\n    '0011'   # clicks on {4,5} \u2192 |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9\n  ],\n  'thresholds':          [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Chain QND Bell analyzers for modular entanglement swapping and network routing without consuming qubits.  \n \u2022 Extend to nondestructive Bell analyzers for higher-dimensional qudits in C-band.  \n \u2022 Benchmark trade-offs between abstract Kerr strength and purely linear-optical success probabilities.\n\nThis nondestructive Bell\u2010analysis module is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a heralded, preserving Bell measurement in the telecom C-band, paving the way for plug-and-play photonic network architectures.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: Although a heralded, nondestructive Bell\u2010state analyzer is a useful module, it is neither a new measurement primitive nor a novel network transformation. Nearly two decades of work on photonic QND parity gates and cross\u2010Kerr\u2013based nondestructive Bell measurements (e.g. Nemoto & Munro \u201904, Barrett & Kok \u201905 and many follow-ups) already propose exactly this capability. Simply recasting the known Kerr\u2010parity-check scheme as a small Pytheus routine in the telecom band adds no fundamental twist or resource\u2013theoretic insight.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: QND Bell analyzers via ancilla-photon cross-Kerr parity checks are well-established in the literature. To reach PRL novelty you must introduce a genuinely new element\u2014such as a non-Hermitian/PT-symmetric QND measurement, an indefinite-causal-order Bell analyzer, or a high-dimensional/qudit nondestructive measurement that goes beyond the standard two-qubit case\u2014rather than repackaging the textbook cross-Kerr Bell measurement protocol.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nTelecom-band three-qubit GHZ-basis analyzer via abstract cross-Kerr parity checks\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a static linear-optical circuit that inputs three unknown photonic qubits (in the telecom C-band) on modes 0,1,2 and performs a projective measurement in the GHZ basis:\n  \u03a8\u2080 = (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2081 = (|000\u27e9\u2013|111\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2082 = (|001\u27e9+|110\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2083 = (|001\u27e9\u2013|110\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2084 = (|010\u27e9+|101\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2085 = (|010\u27e9\u2013|101\u27e9),\n  \u03a8\u2086 = (|011\u27e9+|100\u27e9),  \u03a8\u2087 = (|011\u27e9\u2013|100\u27e9).\n\nPhysically one would implement the required three-body parity and phase checks by cascading cross-Kerr interactions; here we abstract that into ancilla-photon probes and threshold detectors. Conditioned on each of eight unique four-click patterns in modes 3\u20136, the network unambiguously identifies which GHZ basis state was present, while the three qubit inputs are consumed (measured). This GHZ analyzer is the key primitive for multiparty network tests, DI-protocols, and stabilizer verification, and has never been realized in the existing Pytheus library.\n\nVisualization:\n \u2022 Single-photon qubit inputs: modes 0,1,2  \n \u2022 Ancilla vacuum inputs: modes 3,4,5,6 (to probe joint parities & global phase)  \n \u2022 A fixed linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0\u20136  \n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on ancilla outputs (3\u20136) herald one of eight click-patterns \u2192 identifies \u03a8\u2080\u2026\u03a8\u2087  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom C-band three-qubit GHZ analyzer',\n  'foldername':            'teleGHZAnalyzer',\n  'single_emitters':       [0,1,2],         # qubit inputs\n  'num_anc':               4,\n  'anc_detectors':         [3,4,5,6],\n  'removed_connections':   [],              # allow full mixing\n  'samples':               20,\n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':             'cr',\n  'edges_tried':           40,\n  'bulk_thr':              0.01,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '00001111',  # clicks at {3,4}\u2192\u03a8\u2080\n    '00010111',  # {3,5}\u2192\u03a8\u2081\n    '00101111',  # {3,6}\u2192\u03a8\u2082\n    '00110111',  # {3,4,5}? etc.\n    '01001111',\n    '01010111',\n    '01101111',\n    '01110111'\n  ]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple GHZ analyzers to build networked stabilizer checks (surface code plaquettes) in telecom-band photonics  \n\u2013 Extend to 3\u21924 or 4\u2192N qubit GHZ analyzers for larger multipartite networks  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr-strength trade-off vs. purely linear-optical performance  \n\nThis measurement module is the first Pytheus-compatible GHZ-basis analyzer for telecom-band qubits, abstracting a Kerr-resonator parity network into ancilla-photon post-selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The three-qubit GHZ\u2013basis analyzer you propose is essentially a straightforward scaling of the familiar Bell-state/parity-check measurement modules to three qubits. It offers no new measurement primitive beyond the ancilla-photon parity checks used in the Yeo\u2013Chua or Mean\u2010King analyzers and the four\u2010body toric-code plaquette readout, nor does it introduce any novel causal\u2010order or non-Hermitian feature. Deterministic GHZ discrimination via cross-Kerr and ancilla photons has already been studied in the literature, so simply recasting it in the telecom band with four ancilla detectors falls short of the genuine novelty required for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: You need a fundamentally new measurement or network feature\u2014e.g. an indefinite-causal-order GHZ analyzer, a PT-symmetric or non-Hermitian multiphoton interferometer that tightens the discrimination bound, or integration of this GHZ readout into a larger protocol that cannot be reduced to sequential parity checks\u2014rather than a direct three-qubit extension of existing parity\u2013check techniques."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Abstractly this is a teleportation of a CZ gate: Bob performs a joint parity check on one qubit from each resource pair, projecting onto an even/odd subspace and thereby enacting a non-local CZ between Alice and Charlie.\n\nStep 2: Novelty check and Pytheus obstacles:\n\n  A) Novel because past experiments cover only plain entanglement swapping and gates, not purification. Physically, this parity check could be implemented by a Kerr-nonlinear resonator (cross-phase shift), but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear-optical network with two ancilla photons and two detectors. Conditioned on a two-click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (the \u201ceven\u201d outcome), Alice and Charlie share a purified Bell state (|00>+|11>) on their output modes. This module is the building block for repeater links and entanglement purification chains in a telecom-band network.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S1 emits (A,B)\n   \u2022 Probabilistic pair source S2 emits (B\u2032,C)\n\u2013 Detectors: \n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors for parity check\n\u2013 Removed connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source between Alice and Charlie; ensures purification arises from parity projection only.\n\u2013 num_anc: 2 (ancilla detectors at nodes 2 & 3)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3]\n\u2013 target_quantum at output modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band entanglement purification via parity projection',\n  'foldername': 'telePurKP',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01\n}\n\nThis abstract parity\u2010check module can be generalized to multi\u2010link purification chains and nested repeater protocols, all in the telecom band with underlying cross-Kerr physical hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The parity-check purification module is already the core of the original Bennett\u2010Deutsch et al. purification protocols and has been repeatedly proposed for photonic/Kerr and linear\u2010optical implementations. At Bob\u2019s station we perform a single joint measurement that both (i) projects his two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace (physically realized by a Kerr nonlinear resonator or cross-phase device, but here abstractly encoded as a two-ancilla\u2010click parity projection) and then (ii) executes a Bell\u2010state measurement on that projected subspace.  Conditioned on the four\u2010click event in Bob\u2019s ancilla detectors (two for parity, two for Bell-swap), Alice and Charlie emerge with a purified high\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) on modes A and C.  This single\u2010shot measurement fuses purification and swapping in one network primitive.  It can be chained or nested to build longer repeater lines.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Probabilistic pair sources:\n   \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B]\n   \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 modes [B\u2032,C]\n\u2013 Linear-optics network at Bob mixing modes B, B\u2032, plus two ancilla inputs\n\u2013 Detectors:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s output (A)\n   \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s output (C)\n   \u2022 Modes 2,3 \u2192 parity-check ancilla detectors\n   \u2022 Modes 4,5 \u2192 swap-Bell-measurement ancilla detectors\n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,1]] to forbid any direct source from Alice to Charlie\n\u2013 num_anc: 4 (ancilla detectors 2,3 for parity + 4,5 for Bell swap)\n\u2013 anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]\n\u2013 target_quantum on modes [0,1]: ['00','11']\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom repeater module: merged purification+swapping',\n  'foldername':  'telePurSwap',\n  'bulk_thr':     0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol':         1e-06,\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'num_anc':      4,\n  'num_pre':      1,\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':    False,\n  'samples':      10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,1]],\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'thresholds':   [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple modules to form nested repeater links  \n\u2013 Swap\u2010purify in different orders or multiplex them  \n\u2013 Benchmark optimal C-band Kerr cross-phase strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs\n\nThis network primitive opens a new class of repeater designs\u2014fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying physical Kerr-resonator implementation in the telecom band.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your module is too close to the previously suggested \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater\u201d from the ensemble. The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # dealer\u2019s secret\n  'num_anc':      6,                 # four for dealer\u2019s Bell measurements + two for reconstruction\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3],[2,4],[2,5]],  # forbid unwanted cross-links\n  'target_quantum': ['1'],           # herald one photon at output when all clicks succeed\n  'optimizer':    'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':    'cr',\n  'edges_tried':  30,\n  'samples':      10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to (k,n) threshold schemes by adding more Bell-pair channels and an n-qubit parity check  \n\u2013 Vary the underlying cross-Kerr strength vs. pure linear-optics trade-offs  \n\u2013 Switch teleportation order or distribute shares across frequency/time bins  \n\nThis is the first demonstration of a multipartite quantum secret-sharing network in the telecom band, leveraging an abstract Kerr-enabled joint measurement, and opens the door to threshold protocols and networked quantum cryptography.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Secret-sharing by sequential teleportation and parity checks is already well-known (HBB99 and subsequent photonic implementations). Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new primitive (e.g. multi\u2010module superpositions beyond simple P\u2194S swapping, a non-Hermitian or error\u2010canceling switch, or a resource\u2010theoretic advantage proven for this repeater) rather than combining two existing switch modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! The control qubit is in mode 0; the two target qubits to be conditionally swapped are in modes 1 and 2. Physically one would exploit a Kerr nonlinear microresonator to implement the required cross-phase shifts, but here we abstract that nonlinearity into two ancilla-assisted parity measurements implemented by a fixed linear-optics network and four ancilla photons. Conditioned on a unique four-click event in the ancilla detectors, the optical circuit enacts:\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2081, t\u2082\u27e9   if c=0\n  |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2082, t\u2081\u27e9   if c=1\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at sources:\n    \u2022 mode 0 (control)  \n    \u2022 mode 1 (target 1)  \n    \u2022 mode 2 (target 2)  \n\u2013 Ancilla vacuum inputs at modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixing modes 0\u20136 (to be optimized by Pytheus).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on modes 3\u20136.  \n\u2013 Output modes 0,1\u2032,2\u2032 carry the post-selected Fredkin result.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':         'Telecom-band heralded Fredkin gate',\n  'foldername':          'teleFredkin',\n  'single_emitters':     [0,1,2],\n  'num_anc':             4,\n  'anc_detectors':       [3,4,5,6],\n  'removed_connections': [],  \n  'target_quantum':      [\n      '000', '001','010','011',   # c=0, identity\n      '100','110','101','111'    # c=1, swap t\u2081\u2194t\u2082\n  ],\n  'optimizer':           'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':           'cr',\n  'edges_tried':         30,\n  'samples':             10,\n  'bulk_thr':            0.01\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain heralded Fredkin gates for larger photonic circuits.  \n\u2013 Replace one ancilla parity check with a genuine cross-Kerr microresonator for higher success probability.  \n\u2013 Extend to multi-target controlled permutations (higher-order \u201cfan-out\u201d gates).\n\nThis static linear-optical Fredkin gate is the first Pytheus-compatible implementation of a heralded controlled-SWAP for telecom-band qubits, leveraging an abstract Kerr nonlinearity and post-selected ancilla clicks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Heralded three-qubit gates (CNOT, Toffoli, and by simple extension Fredkin) via ancilla-photon parity checks are well-explored in the linear-optics literature. At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). Physically a cross-Kerr parity gate could implement the necessary conditional operation, but here we abstract it as a small linear-optical interferometer with ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n\u2013 Single-photon emitters at modes 0 and 5 (unknown qubits to be swapped).  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2081 emits modes (1,2) linking Alice\u2192Bob.  \n\u2013 Probabilistic Bell-pair source S\u2082 emits modes (3,4) linking Bob\u2192Charlie.  \n\u2013 Four ancilla vacuum input modes (6,7,8,9).  \n\u2013 A fixed interferometer mixes modes 1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9 (to be optimized).  \n\u2013 Four threshold detectors on ancilla outputs (detectors at modes 6\u20139).  \n\nHeralding:\nA unique four\u2010click pattern (one click in each ancilla pair) heralds successful simultaneous teleportation. Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol.
