    "output": "Description:\nTelecom\u2010band path\u2010superposition entanglement router (quantum superposition of network paths)\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear\u2010optical network that distributes entanglement between Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) by coherently superposing two distinct repeater paths\u2014A\u2192B\u2192C and A\u2192D\u2192C\u2014using a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and heralding success via ancilla\u2010photon detections. Physically one could implement each entanglement\u2010swap at B or D via a Kerr cross\u2010phase parity gate; here we abstract both swap modules as ancilla\u2010photon interferometers. The control qubit in |+\u27e9 is split into two arms: in arm 1 it activates the B-swap module; in arm 2 it activates the D-swap module. After recombination and post\u2010selection on a unique click pattern across the control detector and four ancilla detectors, Alice and Charlie share a Bell state that is routed through a coherent superposition of the two network paths. This is the first Pytheus\u2010compatible proposal for superposing network topologies in a photonic repeater.\n\nVisualization:\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 Pair S\u2081 \u2192 modes [A,B\u2081]  \n    \u2013 Pair S\u2082 \u2192 modes [B\u2082,C]  \n    \u2013 Pair S\u2083 \u2192 modes [A,D\u2081]  \n    \u2013 Pair S\u2084 \u2192 modes [D\u2082,C]  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon emitter \u2192 mode Ctrl (control qubit in |+\u27e9)  \n    \u2013 Two ancilla single\u2010photon emitters \u2192 modes Anc\u2081, Anc\u2082 (for parity check at B and D)  \n \u2022 Static interferometer:\n    \u2013 PBS splits Ctrl (H\u2192path B, V\u2192path D)  \n    \u2013 Path B: mixes B\u2081,B\u2082 + Anc\u2081,Anc\u2082 \u2192 detectors {d\u2081,d\u2082} to enact swap_B  \n    \u2013 Path D: mixes D\u2081,D\u2082 + Anc\u2081,Anc\u2082 \u2192 detectors {d\u2083,d\u2084} to enact swap_D  \n    \u2013 Paths recombine at a second PBS \u2192 control detector d_ctrl  \n \u2022 Heralding condition:\n    \u2013 Exactly one click among {d\u2081,d\u2082} or exactly one among {d\u2083,d\u2084}, plus a click at d_ctrl, in a pattern that unambiguously signals which path fired\u2014yet because Ctrl was in |+\u27e9, the network distributes entanglement as a superposition of both paths.  \n \u2022 Output:\n    \u2013 Alice reads mode A; Charlie reads mode C.  Conditioned on the herald, they share (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':           'Telecom\u2010band superposed\u2010path entanglement router',  \n  'foldername':            'telePathSwitch',  \n  'single_emitters':       ['Ctrl','Anc\u2081','Anc\u2082'],  \n  'pair_sources':          [['A','B1'],['B2','C'],['A','D1'],['D2','C']],  \n  'num_anc':               4,             # detectors d\u2081\u2013d\u2084  \n  'anc_detectors':         ['d1','d2','d3','d4'],  \n  'control_detector':      'd_ctrl',  \n  'removed_connections':   [\n     ['B1','D1'],['B1','D2'],['B2','D1'],['B2','D2'],  # forbid cross\u2010talk B\u2194D\n     ['A','C'],['C','A'],['Ctrl','A'],['Ctrl','C']     # direct links forbidden\n  ],  \n  'target_quantum':        ['00','11'],    # on modes [A,C]  \n  'optimizer':             'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'loss_func':             'cr',  \n  'edges_tried':           40,  \n  'samples':               20,  \n  'bulk_thr':              0.01  \n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Extend to superpositions of N different repeater paths (N\u2010arm quantum router) using an N\u2010dimensional control register.  \n\u2013 Chain multiple path\u2010superposition routers for large\u2010scale \u201cquantum internet\u201d experiments.  \n\u2013 Benchmark the trade\u2010off between purely linear\u2010optical realizations and true Kerr\u2010resonator cross\u2010phase implementations in the C-band.\n\nThis primitive opens a new domain of \u201cquantum\u2010coherent network topology\u201d experiments, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract\u2010state, linear\u2010optics, and ancilla\u2010detection framework."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary The Dealer performs two simultaneous Bell measurements\u2014one between her secret and her half of the Bob-pair, one between secret and her half of the Charlie-pair\u2014using a small linear-optical network augmented by a Kerr-enabled parity check (encoded abstractly via two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement). The two classical outcomes from these measurements teleport the secret qubit into two encoded shares held by Bob and Charlie. To reconstruct the secret, Bob and Charlie jointly feed their two qubits into a cross-Kerr equivalent parity-check module (again abstractly a linear-optical ancilla network with two detectors). Conditioned on the correct two-click event, a single photon emerges at a designated reconstruction port, recovering the dealer\u2019s secret. If Bob or Charlie tries alone, no teleportation succeeds.  \n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n   \u2022 S_secret: single-photon emitter \u2192 mode S  \n   \u2022 S_B: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2081,B)  \n   \u2022 S_C: Bell-pair source \u2192 modes (D\u2082,C)  \n\u2013 Dealer\u2019s network: interferes modes S, D\u2081, D\u2082 with 4 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [2,3] for Bell\u2081 and [4,5] for Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Reconstruction network: interferes modes B,C with 2 ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors [6,7] for joint parity  \n\u2013 Output:\n   \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 reconstructed secret photon  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,\u2013]] (no direct Bob\u2192Charlie source)  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom band 2-of-2 quantum secret sharing',\n  'foldername':  'QSS_2of2_teleC',\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # It\u2019s purely a measurement network\u2014no dynamic feedback, no state generation target, only \u201cuse two pair sources + ancilla detectors + post-selection\u201d which Pytheus handles.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea 3.  \nStep 4: \u201cThis idea is novel because it implements the simplest quantum network-coding primitive\u2014the butterfly network for entanglement distribution\u2014via two concurrent Kerr\u2010parity checks in one linear-optical module. No previous Pytheus target realized dual Bell measurements to reroute two links simultaneously.\u201d  \nStep 5: \u201cIt is fully feasible in Pytheus: only three C-band probabilistic pair sources, one small interferometric ancilla network with four extra photons/detectors, removed connections to forbid unwanted direct sources, and a post-selected \u201cfour-click\u201d condition to herald the rerouted entanglement.\u201d\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nQuantum butterfly network for entanglement routing in the telecom C-band\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the C-band:\n  \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n  \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nOur goal is to \u201ccross-connect\u201d them: at the central router node we perform two simultaneous Bell-measurements\u2014one on B-C to entangle A\u2006\u2013\u2006D, and one on B-C in the orthogonal basis to entangle C\u2006\u2013\u2006B\u2032 (i.e. swap both links)\u2014using a single joint network of ancilla photons. Physically one could implement each Bell projection via a cross\u2010Kerr parity check, but here we encode it abstractly as a small linear\u2010optical interferometer with 4 ancilla photons and threshold detectors. Conditioned on the four-click event (two clicks per Bell measurement), Alice (A) and David (D) share one high-fidelity Bell link, and Charlie (C) and Bob (B) share the other. This is the prototypical quantum network coding (\u201cbutterfly\u201d) primitive extended to photonic telecom-band links.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 \u2192 (A,B)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 \u2192 (C,D)  \n\u2013 Central node: linear-optical network mixing modes B & C with 4 ancilla inputs  \n\u2013 Ancilla detectors: modes [2,3] herald Bell\u2081 on (B,C); modes [4,5] herald Bell\u2082  \n\u2013 Output:\n    \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 Alice\u2019s out (A)  \n    \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 David\u2019s out (D)  \n    \u2022 Mode 6 \u2192 Charlie\u2019s out (C)  \n    \u2022 Mode 7 \u2192 Bob\u2019s out (B)  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]] to forbid any direct unwanted source between A\u2194D or C\u2194B  \n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Telecom-band quantum butterfly entanglement router',\n  'foldername':  'teleButterfly',\n  'bulk_thr':    0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'num_anc':     4,\n  'anc_detectors': [2,3,4,5],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'thresholds':  [0.3,0.1],\n  'target_quantum': ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],\n  'optimizer':   'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':   'cr',\n  'samples':     10\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple butterfly nodes for large-scale network coding  \n\u2013 Raise to (k,n) routing by generalizing to multi-port \u201cX-net\u201d units  \n\u2013 Explore trade-off between physical Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optics solutions  \n\nThis primitive opens a new class of photonic telecom-band network coding experiments, fully abstracted for Pytheus and ready for an underlying Kerr-resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your butterfly entanglement router duplicates the ensemble\u2019s existing \u201cButterfly Network\u2010Coded Four\u2010Photon Joint Measurement\u201d and the SiV\u2010based butterfly cross\u2010teleportation schemes. At the central repeater node (Bob), we implement two modules:\n  \u2022 Purification module P: a parity projection on modes B,B\u2032 (abstractly a cross-Kerr parity check \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n  \u2022 Swapping module S: a Bell-state measurement on the post-parity modes (abstractly another ancilla interferometer \u2192 2 ancilla detectors)  \n\nInstead of choosing P\u2192S or S\u2192P statically, we send the control photon through a balanced beam splitter to create |0\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009L, |1\u27e9_ctrl\u2192path\u2009R. In path\u2009L the network applies P then S; in path\u2009R it applies S then P. The two paths are recombined in a Mach\u2013Zehnder and the control is projectively measured in the X basis (via 2 detectors). Conditioned on the six-click event (2 clicks in P, 2 in S, 2 in the control\u2019s X-basis), Alice (mode A) and Charlie (mode C) share a high-fidelity Bell state, and the control qubit\u2019s measurement outcome heralds which coherent superposition of orders was applied. This single static circuit realizes an indefinite-causal-order repeater module.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2013 Sources:\n    \u2022 S_ctrl \u2192 mode  S  (single-photon emitter, control qubit)  \n    \u2022 S\u2081     \u2192 modes A,B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082     \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  \n\u2013 Network at Bob:  \n    \u2022 BS1 splits S into two path modes  \n    \u2022 Path L: P module (mix B,B\u2032 + ancilla inputs \u2192 detectors 2,3) then S module (mix outputs + ancilla \u2192 detectors 4,5)  \n    \u2022 Path R: S module then P module  \n    \u2022 BS2 recombines control paths \u2192 detectors 6,7 (X-basis)  \n\u2013 Detecting clicks [2,3,4,5,6,7] heralds successful superposed\u2010order repeater.  \n\u2013 Alice reads out mode A; Charlie reads out mode C.  \n\u2013 removed_connections: [[A,C]] to forbid direct source from A to C.  \n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  'description':       'Telecom quantum-switch repeater (superposed purification+swapping)',\n  'foldername':        'teleSwitchRep',\n  'single_emitters':   [0],           # mode S is emitter\n  'num_anc':           6,\n  'anc_detectors':     [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  'removed_connections': [[1,2],[1,3]],  # prevent direct B\u2013B\u2032 overlap where needed\n  'target_quantum':    ['00'],        # post-selected Bell on modes [A,C]\n  'optimizer':         'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':         'cr',\n  'edges_tried':       40,\n  'samples':           20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple switch-modules for multi-link networks  \n\u2013 Explore superpositions of different repeater-chain topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark cross-Kerr strength \u2192 switching fidelity vs. pure linear-optics implementations  \n\nThis static linear-optical network is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a photonic quantum switch repeater in the telecom band, ready for an underlying cross-Kerr resonator realization.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the concepts in the ensemble\u2019s indefinite\u2010order purification and swap\u2010order switch proposals. Idea 3 is genuinely new\u2014no Pytheus experiment has realized a static, heralded controlled-swap of network links.\n\nStep 3: I choose idea 3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a three-qubit controlled-entanglement-swapping module (\u201cnetwork-controlled SWAP\u201d) in the telecom C-band. A control photon directs whether Bob swaps Alice\u2019s link to Charlie or leaves both original links intact. No previous Pytheus target realizes controlled re\u2010routing of entanglement.\n\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework: uses two probabilistic C-band Bell-pair sources, one single-photon emitter for the control, a passive interferometer mixing these with two ancilla photons, and four threshold detectors. All operations are static and post-selected\u2014no feedback, no hyper-entanglement, purely linear-optics\u2009+\u2009ancilla.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nTelecom-band controlled entanglement-swapping router (network-controlled SWAP)\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two independent Bell pairs in the telecom C-band:\n \u2022 Pair 1: modes A & B  \n \u2022 Pair 2: modes C & D  \nWe also have a control qubit in mode E (|0\u27e9 or |1\u27e9). At the central router (Bob), we implement a single static linear-optical circuit that performs:\n  \u2013 If control E=|0\u27e9 \u2192 identity: links A\u2013B and C\u2013D remain as Bell pairs  \n  \u2013 If control E=|1\u27e9 \u2192 entanglement\u2010swapping: perform a Bell measurement on B\u2013C and thereby swap entanglement to A\u2013D  \n\nPhysically one could use a Kerr nonlinear resonator to enact the cross-phase conditional gate, but here it is abstracted as a small ancilla-photon interferometer. Two ancilla vacuum modes (F,G) enter the circuit; four threshold detectors herald success with a unique four-click pattern. The five surviving output modes are:\n  0 \u2192 Alice (A)  \n  1 \u2192 Bob\u2019s post-router port (either B or swapped-C)  \n  2 \u2192 Charlie (D)  \n  3 \u2192 unused (vacuum)  \n  4 \u2192 control (E)  \n\nConditioned on the correct ancilla pattern at detectors H,I,J,K, the five-qubit output state on modes [0,1,2,4] is\n  \u2022 If E=0: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AB}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{CD}\u2297|0\u27e9_E  \n  \u2022 If E=1: |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{AD}\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{BC}\u2297|1\u27e9_E  \n\nThese two scenarios are coherently addressed by the same static network, thus enacting a controlled-entanglement-swap. This primitive generalizes to reconfigurable quantum networks and can be cascaded for programmable photonic routing in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom-band controlled entanglement-swap router',\n  'foldername':           'teleCtrlSwap',\n  'single_emitters':      [4],               # mode E\n  'num_anc':              2,                 # ancilla F,G\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6],             # detectors H,I at F,G\n  'removed_connections':  [],                # no extra direct links\n  'target_quantum':       [\n    # control=0: AB & CD Bell pairs\n    '0000000',  # |000\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} \n    '0010010',  # |001\u27e9_{A,B,C,D,E} etc.\n    '1101100',\n    '1111110',\n    # control=1: AD & BC Bell pairs\n    '0000001',\n    '0101101',\n    '1010011',\n    '1111111'\n  ],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          30,\n  'samples':              20\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Use multiple control qubits for programmable multi-link routing  \n\u2013 Chain controlled-swap routers into larger network topologies  \n\u2013 Benchmark abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical success probabilities  \n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a controlled entanglement-swap router in the telecom C-band, paving the way to reconfigurable quantum photonic networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This controlled entanglement\u2010swap router duplicates existing network\u2010coding and controlled\u2010SWAP proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s butterfly protocol and spectral\u2010control router). Conditioned on that pattern, the output mode 0\u2032 (Alice\u2019s port) carries Charlie\u2019s original qubit, and mode 5\u2032 (Charlie\u2019s port) carries Alice\u2019s original qubit.  \n\nTarget mapping on the two output modes [0\u2032,5\u2032] in the computational basis is the \u201cswap\u201d map:\n00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom C-band bidirectional teleportation',\n  'foldername':           'teleBiTeleport',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,5],           # Alice & Charlie inputs\n  'num_anc':              4,\n  'anc_detectors':        [6,7,8,9],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,5],[1,4]],   # forbid any direct unwanted links\n  'samples':              20,\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum':       ['00','10','01','11']\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain multiple bidirectional\u2010swap modules for multi-channel photonic networks  \n\u2013 Extend to higher\u2010dimensional (\u201cqudit\u201d) swap-teleportation in C-band  \n\u2013 Benchmark success vs. varying abstract Kerr strength vs. purely linear-optical realizations\n\nThis is the first Pytheus-compatible proposal for a simultaneous two-way teleportation primitive in the telecom band, ready for a future cross-Kerr resonator implementation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation protocol.     "output": "Description:\nUniversal entanglement-fusion module in the telecom C-band  \n\u2013 A single static linear-optical circuit that \u201cfuses\u201d two incoming Bell\u2013pair links (A\u2013M and M\u2013B) into either  \n    \u2022 a direct A\u2013B Bell link (entanglement swap), or  \n    \u2022 a three-party GHZ link A\u2013M\u2013B  \n  depending on which ancilla-click pattern occurs\u2014no active feed-forward, no dynamic control.\n\nExplanation:\n1) Sources:  \n   \u2022 S\u2081 emits a probabilistic Bell pair on modes (0,3) connecting Alice (mode 0) to the router node M\u2081 (mode 3).  \n   \u2022 S\u2082 emits a probabilistic Bell pair on modes (1,4) connecting router node M\u2082 (mode 4) to Bob (mode 1).  \n2) At node M:  \n   \u2022 We inject one single-photon ancilla into mode 2.  \n   \u2022 A fixed interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes [2,3,4] with two vacuum-ancilla inputs (modes 5,6).  \n   \u2022 Four threshold detectors on modes [5,6,7,8] herald the fusion outcome.  \n3) Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 Clicks on detectors {5,6} \u21d2 entanglement-swap outcome  \n     \u2022 Alice and Bob\u2019s output modes (0,1) collapse onto a Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{01}.  \n   \u2013 Clicks on detectors {7,8} \u21d2 GHZ-fusion outcome  \n     \u2022 Modes (0,2,1) collapse onto |GHZ\u27e9 = (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9)/\u221a2 across (Alice, M, Bob).  \n4) Outputs:  \n   \u2013 In both cases the surviving photonic modes at Alice (0), M (2) and Bob (1) emerge undisturbed and entangled according to the outcome.  \n\nThis universal module thus acts as a \u201cplug-and-play\u201d network-fusion gate: it can extend a Bell chain (swap) or broadcast entanglement (GHZ) in one shot, simply by post-selecting on which ancilla detectors click. Chaining several such modules yields reconfigurable photonic network topologies in the telecom band.\n\nPytheus-style config sketch:\n{\n  'description':          'Telecom universal entanglement-fusion module',\n  'foldername':           'teleFusion',\n  'samples':              20,\n  'single_emitters':      [2],              # ancilla at mode 2\n  'num_anc':              4,                # detectors on modes 5\u20138\n  'anc_detectors':        [5,6,7,8],\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,1]],          # forbid any direct Bell source between Alice and Bob\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'edges_tried':          40,\n  'bulk_thr':             0.01,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # Swap outcome on modes [0,1,5,6]: '1100' clicks at 5&6  \u21d2 Bell_{01}\n    '1100',\n    # GHZ outcome on modes [0,1,2,7,8]: '11100' clicks at 7&8 \u21d2 GHZ_{0,2,1}\n    '11100'\n  ],\n  'thresholds':           [0.3,0.1]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n\u2022 Nest modules to build long-distance repeater chains that can dynamically choose swap vs. branching  \n\u2022 Extend to k-link fusion: fuse k incoming Bell edges into k\u2013party GHZ states conditioned on ancilla patterns  \n\u2022 Benchmark performance vs. abstract Kerr cross-phase strength and purely linear-optical alternatives  \n\nThis universal fusion gate\u2014combining entanglement swapping and GHZ broadcast in one static C-band circuit\u2014opens a new class of reconfigurable photonic quantum networks."
